questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following layers is not present in the cardiac valve?
questions.explanation:
Adventitia is not a layer of the cardiac valves. It is the outermost layer of a blood vessel. It 
contains connective tissue, a few cells, macrophages, mast cells, fibroblasts, and the nerves and 
vessels that supply the vascular wall. Cardiac valves are lined by endothelium and share a tri-layered architecture: • Fibrosa is a dense collagenous core at the outflow surface. It is connected to the valvular 
supporting structures. • Spongiosa is a central core of loose connective tissue • Ventricularis or atrialis is a layer rich in elastin on the inflow surface. 701 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 2: You are conducting an autopsy of an elderly patient who was found dead in his home. Which 
of the following changes in the heart will not be suggestive of normal aging?
questions.explanation:
In the given scenario, an increase in the size of the left ventricle is not normally seen in the heart 
of an elderly person. The size of the left ventricular cavity is decreased in the aged heart, 
particularly in the base-to-apex dimension. This change is exacerbated by systemic hypertension. Changes in the aging heart: • Chambers: • Increased left atrial cavity size • Decreased left ventricular cavity size • Valves: • Fibrous thickening of valve leaflets • Aortic and mitral valve calcific deposits • Epicardial coronary arteries: • Diminished compliance • Calcific deposits • Atherosclerotic plaques • Myocardium: • Increased subepicardial fat • Brown atrophy • Lipofuscin deposition • Basophilic degeneration • Amyloid deposits • Aorta: • Dilated with a rightward shift • Elastic fragmentation and collagen accumulation • Atherosclerotic plaque

questions.question: Question 3: What type of cells are heart failure cells?
questions.explanation:
Heart failure cells are hemosiderin-laden macrophages. They are telltale signs of previous 
episodes of pulmonary edema. In cardiac failure, red cells and plasma proteins extravasate into the edema fluid within the 
alveolar spaces. These are then phagocytosed and digested by macrophages. The iron recovered 
from haemoglobin is stored in the form of hemosiderin. The image given below shows heart failure cells within alveolar spaces. 702 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 4: What is the most common cause of left-sided diastolic heart failure?
questions.explanation:
Hypertension is the most common cause of left-sided diastolic heart failure. Left-sided heart failure can be divided into systolic and diastolic failure. Diastolic failure 
predominantly occurs in patients older than age 65 years. Here, the left ventricle is abnormally 
stiff and cannot relax during diastole. Causes of diastolic heart failure: • Hypertension: most common • Diabetes mellitus • Obesity • Bilateral renal artery stenosis 703 
Sold by @itachibot Systolic failure is due to insufficient ejection fraction, i.e., pump failure. It occurs when the 
contractile function of the left ventricle is deranged.

questions.question: Question 5: Which of the following does not cause isolated right-sided heart failure?
questions.explanation:
Isolated right-sided heart failure is not caused by left-sided heart failure. Isolated right-sided heart failure is not common and usually occurs in patients with disorders 
affecting the lungs. Therefore, it is often referred to as cor pulmonale. It is caused by disorders of 
the lung parenchyma and pulmonary vasculature. It is also caused by conditions causing 
pulmonary vasoconstriction like obstructive sleep apnea and altitude sickness. Pulmonary hypertension is the common feature of these disorders, which leads to hypertrophy 
and dilation of the right side of the heart. Right-sided heart failure is most commonly caused by left-sided heart failure. This is because an 
increase in pressure in the pulmonary circulation from left-sided failure burdens the right side of 
the heart.

questions.question:
Question 6: A massive pulmonary embolism occurs in a patient with acute cor-pulmonale. What 
pathological changes do you expect in the heart of this patient?
questions.explanation:
In the given scenario, the patient has acute cor pulmonale. This causes right ventricular dilation 
without hypertrophy. On cross-section, the normal crescent shape of the right ventricle is 
transformed to a dilated ovoid. In chronic cor pulmonale, the right ventricular wall thickens. The hypertrophied right ventricle 
may compress the left ventricular chamber. It can also cause regurgitation and fibrous thickening 
of the tricuspid valve.

questions.question:
Question 7: The liver specimen obtained after the autopsy of a patient is given below. What could be the 
likely cause of this finding? 693 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
In the image, the liver specimen shows a nutmeg liver appearance, which occurs in congestive 
hepatomegaly. This is secondary to passive congestion due to right heart failure. In right heart failure, there is congestion of hepatic and portal vessels, greatest around the central 
veins. This leads to increased liver size and weight. The pericentral zones become congested and 
red-brown. The periportal regions are normal coloured and tan. This leads to a nutmeg liver 
appearance. With longstanding failure, the central areas can become fibrotic, eventually 
culminating in cardiac cirrhosis. Pathological changes are also seen in the spleen and the gastrointestinal tract. Portal venous 
hypertension also causes the enlargement of the spleen, with platelet sequestration. This is known 
as congestive splenomegaly. This can also contribute to chronic congestion and oedema of the 
bowel. 704 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 8: Which hormone reduces the risk of myocardial infarction in women of reproductive age?
questions.explanation:
Estrogen reduces the risk of myocardial infarction in women in the reproductive age group. Accelerated coronary artery disease is associated with the postmenopausal decline in estrogen 
production. However, postmenopausal hormonal replacement therapy (HRT) has not been shown 
to be beneficial. The most common cause of death in older women is ischemic heart disease. Through middle age, males have a relatively increased risk of myocardial infarction.

questions.question:
Question 9: A 65-year-old man presented to the casualty with severe, sudden-onset chest pain radiating to 
the left arm. ECG showed ST-segment elevation in precordial leads. The person succumbed 
after 3 hours. On autopsy, the patient's heart was immersed in triphenyl tetrazolium chloride 
solution. What colour would be imparted to the heart?

options.b: Viable myocardium appears brick red and infarct appears pale
options.c: Viable myocardium appears red and infarct appears dark blue
options.d: Viable myocardium appears unstained and the infarct appears dark red

questions.explanation:
Triphenyl tetrazolium chloride solution imparts a brick red colour to the viable non-infarcted 
myocardium. The infarct appears unstained and pale. Myocardial infarcts < 12 hours old are usually not apparent on gross examination. However, if 
the infarct preceded death by 2 to 3 hours, it is possible to identify the area of necrosis. This is 
done by immersing the tissue slices in triphenyl tetrazolium chloride solution. The histochemical stain imparts a brick-red colour to intact, noninfarcted myocardium. 
Here, lactate dehydrogenase, LDH, activity is preserved. LDH leaks out through the damaged 
membranes of dead cells, so an infarct appears as an unstained pale zone. The image given below shows an ischemic brain after immersion in triphenyl tetrazolium chloride 
solution. The pale unstained region is the infarcted zone.

questions.question: Question 10: What is the approximate time of onset of microvascular injury in ischemic cardiac myocytes?
questions.explanation:
Microvascular injury begins >1 hour after the onset of ischemia. 705 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 11: What is the earliest detectable ultrastructural feature of myocardial infarction?
questions.explanation:
Relaxation of myofibrils is the earliest detectable ultrastructural feature of myocardial infarction. Myofibril relaxation, mitochondrial swelling and glycogen loss can be detected by electron 
microscopy within half an hour of myocardial infarction.

questions.question:
Question 12: You are conducting the autopsy of a patient who passed away following myocardial infarction. 
What would be the earliest light microscopic change that can be observed in the heart of this 
patient?
questions.explanation:
The earliest light microscopic change that can be observed in the heart of this patient is 
the waviness of myocardial fibres. This is seen within ½-4 hours at the border of the infarct. These changes are a result of the forceful contractions of viable fibres. The contractions cause 
stretching and buckling of immediately adjacent, noncontractile dead fibres. Myocyte vacuolization or myocytolysis may also be seen in the infarct margins. It is due to the 
accumulation of salt and water in the sarcoplasmic reticulum. Such myocytes are viable but poorly 
contractile. The image below shows microscopic features of myocardial infarction showing wavy myocardial 
fibres. There are wavy fibres that are elongated and narrow, as compared with normal fibres. The 
widened spaces between the dead fibres contain edema fluid and scattered neutrophils.

questions.question: Question 13: Following myocardial infarction, coagulative necrosis begins at?
questions.explanation:
Early coagulative necrosis begins in myocardial infarction by 4–12 hours. However, it is prominent between 1 to 3 days after myocardial infarction. 706 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 14: The heart of a patient who had suffered a myocardial infarction is subjected to a 
histopathological examination. The microscopic image is given below. What time following 
infarction would you observe this?
questions.explanation:
The given image shows neutrophilic infiltration into the myocardium. Early neutrophil infiltration 
starts by 12–24 hours following the infarction. It can be visualised by examination with a light 
microscope. The necrotic myocardium elicits acute inflammation most prominent between 1 and 3 
days. During this time, there is a brisk interstitial infiltrate of neutrophils. The image given below shows neutrophilic infiltration into the myocardium following MI.

questions.question:
Question 15: A patient was admitted four days back following acute myocardial infarction. What type of 
cells would you expect to see in the infarcted area in this patient?
questions.explanation:
In the given scenario, 4 days after MI, macrophages are seen in the infarcted area. They phagocytose dead myocytes at the border of the infarct earliest by 72 hours. Removal of the 
necrotic myocytes is most noticeable by 3 to 7 days. The image below shows a macrophagic infiltrate in the infarcted area. 707 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 16: Match the following:
questions.explanation: The correct match is: • Well established granulation - 10 - 14 days • Complete scarring - > 2 months • Myocyte hypereosinophilia - 12 - 24 hours • Grey white scar - 2-8 weeks • Loss of nuclei and striations - 1 - 3 days

questions.question:
Question 17: A 67-year-old woman is found dead in her home. On autopsy, hemopericardium secondary to 
ventricular wall rupture is seen. How long before her death did she probably have a 
myocardial infarction?
questions.explanation:
The given autopsy finding of hemopericardium secondary to ventricular wall rupture occurs most 
frequently 3-7 days after myocardial infarction (MI). During this time, the lysis of the necrotic 
myocardium is maximum. Thus most of the infarct has been converted to friable granulation 
tissue. The risk factors for free-wall rupture are: • Age > 60 years • Female gender • First MI • Large, transmural and anterior MI • Absence of left ventricular hypertrophy • Preexisting hypertension 708 
Sold by @itachibot It is less frequent in patients with prior MI because associated fibrotic scarring inhibits 
myocardial tearing. Complications of MI: • Heart failure - • This is due to ventricular dysfunction caused by the infarct and ventricular remodeling • Usually occurs within a day • Cardiogenic shock - • This is usually seen in severe multivessel coronary artery disease due to extensive involvement of 
myocardium • Usually occurs within a day • Arrhythmias - most common complication, occurring usually 2 days after infarction • Most common arrhythmia within one hour of MI - ventricular fibrillation • Most common arrhythmia after one hour of MI - supraventricular tachycardia • Myocardial rupture - occurs when there is transmural necrosis of a ventricle. It includes the 
following - • Left ventricular free wall rupture (most common) - leads to cardiac tamponade • Interventricular septal rupture - leads acute ventricular septal defect (VSD) • Papillary muscle rupture - leads to severe mitral regurgitation • Mitral regurgitation (MR) - this can occur due to - • Transient papillary muscle dysfunction - mid-systolic or late-systolic murmur • Rupture of papillary muscle - pansystolic murmur • Dressler syndrome (post-MI syndrome) - • This is an immune-mediated reaction and presents as pericarditis, pleurisy, and fever • It can occur even 48 hrs after MI but usually occurs 1–6 weeks after MI and often subside after a 
few days • Ventricular aneurysm • Infarct expansion associated with mural thrombus

questions.question: Question 18: What causes tigered myocardium?
questions.explanation:
Tigered myocardium appearance occurs as a result of prolonged moderate hypoxia due to fatty 
change. It is the gross appearance of the heart with bands of yellow myocardium alternating with 
normal myocardium.

questions.question: Question 19: Which of the following causes the maximum damage in reperfusion injury?
questions.explanation:
709 
Sold by @itachibot In reperfusion injury, the maximum damage is caused by free radicals. Reperfusion is the restoration of blood flow to the ischemic myocardium threatened by infarction. 
Reperfused infarcts are usually hemorrhagic because the vasculature is injured during ischemia. 
Once the flow is restored, there is bleeding. On microscopic examination, the irreversibly injured myocytes exhibit contraction bands that are 
intensely eosinophilic intracellular stripes. These contraction bands are composed of closely 
packed sarcomeres. Reperfusion injury may be mediated by: • Oxidative stress • Calcium overload • Inflammatory cells recruited after tissue reperfusion

questions.question: Question 20: What creatine kinase isoenzymes do the heart muscle contain?
questions.explanation:
Heart muscle contains MM and MB isoenzymes of creatine kinase. Creatine kinase (CK) has three isoenzymes: • CK-1 (BB) - brain, nerve tissue, prostate (small amounts), intestine, lung, bladder, kidney, uterus, 
thyroid • CK-2 (MB) - heart and skeletal muscle • CK-3 (MM) - skeletal and heart muscle Elevation of the CK-MB isoforms is seen in MI. CK-MB is less 
sensitive and less specific, therefore, troponins are preferred for the diagnosis of MI. CK-MB 
begins to rise within 3-12 hours of the onset of MI. It peaks at about 24 hours and returns to 
normal within approximately 48-72 hours.

questions.question:
Question 21: A patient comes to the hospital after 3 hours of the onset of chest pain. ECG reveals 
ST-segment elevation in the precordial leads. Which of the following enzymes would be 
elevated in this patient?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario is suggestive of acute myocardial infarction (MI). Enzymes elevated after 4 to 8 
hours of MI are CK-MB (creatine kinase MB) and troponins. When cardiac troponin is available, CK-MB should not be used for the initial diagnosis of acute 
MI. If it is the only assay available, it can be used, but it is far less sensitive and less specific.

questions.question:
Question 22: A 56-year-old man presented to the emergency department with progressive dyspnoea. His 
wife reports that he had chest pain 7 days back which had lasted for 2 days. You suspect that 
the patient's chest pain was due to myocardial infarction. If so, blood levels of which of the 
following enzymes would be elevated now?
questions.explanation:
In the given scenario, on post-MI day 7, troponin and LDH will be raised. Troponins are highly 
specific for MI and remain elevated for 7 to 10 days. 710 
Sold by @itachibot Troponins are proteins that regulate calcium-mediated contraction of the cardiac and skeletal 
muscles. It is the single biomarker preferred for diagnosing MI, late diagnosis of MI, and 
diagnosis of reinfarction. Troponin I is more important than troponin T. Cardiac troponin increases rapidly in patients with reinfarction. Sometimes, the cardiac troponin 
concentration is elevated, but stable or decreasing at the time of suspected reinfarction. Then 
the diagnosis of reinfarction requires a 20% or greater increase in the cTn measurement. Myoglobin is the earliest enzyme to increase after MI. It is a protein that is found in the skeletal 
and cardiac muscles, which binds oxygen. It is a very sensitive indicator of muscle injury. But it is 
not specific to cardiac muscle and can be elevated to any form of injury to skeletal muscle. 
Myoglobin and SGOT levels come to baseline before day 1.

questions.question:
Question 23: The blood levels of various cardiac biomarkers are measured in a patient following 
myocardial infarction. This is represented in the given graph. Which biomarker does the 
yellow curve depict? 698 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The yellow curve here shows the levels of CK-MB which starts rising around 4 to 8 hrs post-MI, 
peaks at 24 hours and becomes normal at 48 to 72 hrs. The post-myocardial infarction blood levels of the different cardiac biomarkers are shown in the 
image given below.

questions.question:
Question 24: Loss-of-function mutation in potassium channel gene KCNQ1 results in which of the 
following?
questions.explanation:
Loss of function mutation in K+ channel genes KCNQ1 and KCNH2 produces the long QT 
syndrome. The gain-of-function mutation produces the short QT syndrome. Long QT syndrome manifests as arrhythmias associated with excessive prolongation of cardiac 
repolarization. Stress-induced syncope or sudden cardiac death (SCD), are common presentations. Short QT syndrome presents with arrhythmias associated with abbreviated repolarization 
intervals. They also present with palpitations, syncope, and SCD. 711 
Sold by @itachibot Brugada syndrome manifests as ECG abnormalities like ST-segment elevations and right 
bundle-branch block. This occurs in the absence of structural heart disease. Here, patients 
classically present with syncope or SCD during rest or sleep or after large meals. Familial atrial fibrillation is caused by a gain of function mutation in genes coding potassium 
channels.

questions.question: Question 25: What is the most common mechanism behind sudden cardiac death?
questions.explanation:
The mechanism behind sudden cardiac death (SCD) is most often a lethal arrhythmia, e.g., 
asystole or ventricular fibrillation. Coronary artery disease is the leading cause of SCD, responsible for 80% to 90% of cases. But, the 
mechanism of SCD is most often a lethal arrhythmia. Infarction need not occur. Most of the 
patients who have SCD but are successfully resuscitated do not show any enzymatic or ECG 
evidence of myocardial necrosis. Ischemic injury can directly affect the major components of the conduction system. But, most 
cases of fatal arrhythmia are triggered by electrical irritability of the myocardium.

questions.question:
Question 26: Patients with which of the following conditions have an increased susceptibility to coronary 
artery disease?
questions.explanation:
Patients with hyperlipidemia have an increased susceptibility to coronary artery disease (CAD). Hyperlipidemia is considered the second most common risk factor for CAD worldwide after 
hypertension. Hypercholesterolemia was implicated in 55% of cases with combined 
hyperlipidemia in 41% cases.

questions.question: Question 27: What is lipoprotein a [Lp (a)] composed of?
questions.explanation:
Lipoprotein a [Lp(a)] contains the apolipoprotein B-100 portion of LDL linked to apolipoprotein A 
(apo A). It is an altered form of low-density lipoprotein (LDL). Increased Lp(a) levels are associated with coronary and cerebrovascular disease risk. It is 
independent of total cholesterol or LDL levels.

questions.question: Question 28: Histology of reperfused myocardium:
questions.explanation:
Reperfused myocardium shows eosinophilic contraction bands on light microscopy. They occur 
in irreversibly injured myocytes with damaged membranes, when blood supply is restored 12-24 
hours after MI. During ischemia, the intracellular levels of calcium are increased due to impaired calcium cycling 
and sarcolemmal damage. This leads to augmented and uncontrolled contraction of myofibrils 712 
Sold by @itachibot after reperfusion. On microscopic examination, the irreversibly injured myocytes exhibit contraction bands that are 
intensely eosinophilic intracellular stripes. These contraction bands are composed of closely 
packed sarcomeres. Reperfused infarcts are usually hemorrhagic because the vasculature is injured during ischemia. 
This leads to bleeding after the flow is restored. 713 
Sold by @itachibot Myocardial and Pericardial Diseases and Cardiac Tumors
